Guidelines: Extract how resident arrived from nurse's description: ambulatory (walked in), stretcher (lying down transport), or wheelchair

Priority order for vital signs documentation: (1) Use nurse's verbal report from audio if available. (2) If nurse has not taken vitals or this is a new admission, extract existing data from PCC system. (3) If neither audio nor PCC data exists, leave fields empty.

Actual Question: Cognitive Orientation (person, place, time, situation, comatose)
Guidelines: If orientation not formally tested, infer from interactions during admission: appropriate responses to questions about name/why they're here (oriented to person/situation), knows current year or season (oriented to time), recognizes they're in a facility (oriented to place), no meaningful interaction (comatose). Mark all that apply based on conversation. Be conservative - only assume orientation if clear evidence of awareness during admission interaction.

Actual Question: Comatose Care Plan (auto-populates if comatose selected)
Special Needs on Admission (hospice, respite, palliative care)
Hospice Care Plan (auto-populates if hospice selected)

Guidelines: Extract code status ONLY if nurse states from advance directive or states physician order ("physician confirmed DNR" or "Full Code per transfer orders"). This is legal documentation - do not assume.

Actual Question: MD contacted and order obtained for code status
Full Code Care Plan (auto-populates if Full Code selected)
DNR Care Plan (auto-populates if DNR selected)
Resident oriented to facility and room
Guidelines: Mark "Yes" if nurse mentions explaining room features, bathroom location, call light use, or facility rules. Mark "No" if not mentioned or resident unable to participate.

Actual Question: Does resident have valuables on site

Guidelines: Write any pertinent admission comments/observations that were not documented above, be conservative.

Extract stated goals if discussed with resident/family. If not explicitly discussed but nurse mentions "admitted for rehab after hip surgery," assume "Discharge to Community." If nurse mentions "long-term placement" or "no discharge plan," mark "Remain LTC." When uncertain, mark "Discharge to Community" as default for skilled rehab admission

Actual Question: Therapy Ordered on Admission (PT, OT, ST)
Therapy Care Plan (auto-populates if therapy ordered)

Guidelines: As nurse reads admission medication list aloud, identify and mark all medication classes present. Common classifications: Metoprolol/Carvedilol/Lisinopril = Cardiac; Hydrocodone/Oxycodone/Morphine = Pain; Cipro/Levaquin/Augmentin = Antibiotic; Lasix/Bumex = Diuretic; Warfarin/Eliquis/Xarelto = Anticoagulant; Insulin/Metformin/Glipizide = Diabetic; Prozac/Zoloft/Lexapro = Antidepressant; Ativan/Xanax/Klonopin = Antianxiety; Ambien/Lunesta/Trazodone = Sedative/Hypnotic; Seroquel/Risperdal/Zyprexa = Antipsychotic; Keppra/Gabapentin/Depakote = Anticonvulsant; Albuterol/Advair/Spiriva = Respiratory; Omeprazole/Pantoprazole = Gastrointestinal; Flomax/Detrol = Genitourinary; Synthroid/Levothyroxine = Thyroid.

Actual Question: Does resident choose to self-administer medications

Guidelines: Extract if nurse tests resident's ability to read medication labels or identify medications by sight. Mark "Fully capable" if resident reads labels correctly or identifies all medications. Mark "Unable" if cannot read labels or identify medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Actual Question: Can resident state what each medication is for
Guidelines: Extract if nurse asks resident to explain purpose of each medication. Mark "Fully capable" if resident correctly states therapeutic purpose (e.g., "for blood pressure," "for pain"). Mark "Unable" if cannot explain purposes. Leave blank if not tested.

Actual Question: Can resident state correct timing for medications
Guidelines: Extract if nurse asks resident when to take each medication. Mark "Fully capable" if resident correctly states timing (e.g., "morning," "twice daily," "at bedtime"). Mark "Unable" if cannot state correct timing. Leave blank if not tested.

Actual Question: Can resident state correct medication dosage
Guidelines: Extract if nurse asks resident to state how much medication to take. Mark "Fully capable" if resident correctly states dosage (e.g., "one tablet," "two pills"). Mark "Unable" if cannot state correct dosage. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if nurse observes resident opening pill bottles, blister packs, or other containers. Mark "Fully capable" if resident opens containers independently. Mark "Unable" if cannot open containers despite attempts. Leave blank if not tested.

Actual Question: Can resident measure appropriate medication amounts
Guidelines: Extract if nurse observes resident pouring or removing correct number of pills/amount of liquid medication. Mark "Fully capable" if resident measures accurately. Mark "Unable" if cannot measure correctly. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if nurse tests resident's ability to record medication administration (writing date/time, initialing form). Mark "Fully capable" if resident documents correctly. Mark "Unable" if cannot document properly. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if nurse assesses how resident will store medications safely (locked box, drawer, away from others). Mark "Fully capable" if resident demonstrates appropriate storage plan. Mark "Unable" if cannot secure medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Actual Question: Can resident state PRN medication situations
Guidelines: Extract if nurse asks when to take as-needed medications. Mark "Fully capable" if resident correctly identifies when PRN needed (e.g., "when pain is severe," "if I have heartburn"). Mark "Capable with assistance" if understands with prompting. Mark "Unable" if cannot identify appropriate use. Mark "N/A" if no PRN medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if resident demonstrates giving self-injections (insulin, blood thinners). Mark "Fully capable" if performs injection correctly with proper technique. Mark "Capable with assistance" if needs setup help. Mark "Unable" if cannot perform safely. Mark "N/A" if no injectable medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if resident demonstrates using inhaler or nebulizer. Mark "Fully capable" if uses correct technique independently. Mark "Capable with assistance" if needs reminders on technique. Mark "Unable" if cannot use properly. Mark "N/A" if no inhalant medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if resident demonstrates applying eye drops or ointment. Mark "Fully capable" if administers correctly to correct eye. Mark "Capable with assistance" if needs help positioning bottle. Mark "Unable" if cannot administer safely. Mark "N/A" if no eye medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if resident demonstrates applying topical medications to correct location. Mark "Fully capable" if applies correctly per orders. Mark "Capable with assistance" if needs reminders. Mark "Unable" if cannot apply properly. Mark "N/A" if no topical medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if resident demonstrates applying ear drops. Mark "Fully capable" if administers correctly to correct ear. Mark "Capable with assistance" if needs help positioning. Mark "Unable" if cannot administer safely. Mark "N/A" if no ear medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if resident demonstrates understanding of suppository administration. Mark "Fully capable" if can explain/demonstrate proper technique. Mark "Capable with assistance" if needs setup help. Mark "Unable" if cannot perform safely. Mark "N/A" if no rectal medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if resident demonstrates understanding of vaginal suppository administration. Mark "Fully capable" if can explain/demonstrate proper technique. Mark "Capable with assistance" if needs setup help. Mark "Unable" if cannot perform safely. Mark "N/A" if no vaginal medications. Leave blank if not tested.

Extract if nurse asks when to request medication refills. Mark "Fully capable" if resident understands when supply runs low and how to request refills. Mark "Capable with assistance" if needs reminders. Mark "Unable" if cannot manage refills. Mark "N/A" if facility manages all refills. Leave blank if not tested.

Actual Question: Vision Care Plan (auto-populates if vision problems)
Hearing Care Plan (auto-populates if hearing problems)

Guidelines: If communication ability not explicitly assessed, infer from interactions: normal conversation throughout audio (verbal), difficulty speaking or nurse mentions communication barriers (mark alternative methods), language barriers mentioned (interpreter needed), uses writing or gestures (mark accordingly). Only mark alternative communication methods if clearly needed, otherwise assume verbal communication.

Actual Question: Does resident have appliance at facility

Guidelines: Extract findings if nurse examines mouth and dictates observations. Mark "unable to examine" if no oral exam performed - full oral assessment may not occur within 24 hours of admission. Do not assume oral health status without documented examination.

Mark specific behaviors only if clearly stated or observed: family reports wandering, agitation noted during admission, exit-seeking mentioned, physical aggression described. If resident cooperative and appropriate throughout admission interaction, mark "no behavior symptoms present." Be conservative - only mark behavioral problems if explicitly documented or observed, not based on diagnoses alone.

Extract ADL assistance needs if explicitly discussed. If not specified, infer from admission observations: arrived by stretcher (likely needs mobility/transfer assist), needed help to bathroom (toileting assist), nurse describes assisting with tasks. If ambulatory admission with no assistance mentioned and resident managing independently, assume independent unless limitations stated. Use observations of how resident functioned during admission process.

Actual Question: Does resident require mechanical lift for transfers
Is head of bed elevated to prevent SOB
Can light and smoke cigarette safely
Determination: safe smoker or impaired smoker
Smoking policy given to resident/responsible party
Is resident receiving antipsychotic medication requiring AIMS
Guidelines: If antipsychotic medication status not explicitly stated, infer from medication lists or diagnoses: presence of medications like haloperidol, risperidone, quetiapine, aripiprazole, or diagnoses requiring antipsychotic treatment (AIMS required), absence of these medications (AIMS not required).

Actual Question: Neck, Shoulders and Hips movement assessment
Date of pain onset if known

Guidelines: For non-communicative residents, mark pain behaviors nurse observes: grimacing, moaning, guarding, restlessness, tensed body, distressed appearance. Only mark indicators clearly observed and documented in audio. Do not mark based on diagnosis alone without observed behaviors

If pain relief preferences not formally assessed but pain is present, infer from treatment documentation and patient responses: scheduled pain medications (medication management), mentions of positioning for comfort (repositioning), use of heat/cold therapy (warm/cold compresses), other documented comfort measures. Only document methods that show evidence of effectiveness or patient preference.

Actual Question: Is resident satisfied with pain control
Explanation if not satisfied with pain control
Sensory perception - ability to respond to pressure discomfort
Guidelines: Score based on nurse's observations and information stated during admission. If not formally assessed question-by-question, score using nurse's general description of resident's condition. Infer from cognitive status and pain responses - normal cognition + appropriate pain responses (no impairment/4 points), responds to commands but limited communication (slightly limited/3 points), responds only to painful stimuli or has sensory deficits (very limited/2 points), unresponsive or heavily sedated (completely limited/1 point).

Actual Question: Moisture - degree skin exposed to moisture
Guidelines: Score based on nurse's observations and information stated during admission. If not formally assessed question-by-question, score using nurse's general description of resident's condition Assess from incontinence status and documented skin conditions - continent with dry skin (rarely moist/4 points), occasional incontinence episodes (occasionally moist/3 points), frequent moisture issues requiring linen changes (very moist/2 points), constant incontinence or perspiration (constantly moist/1 point).

Score based on nurse's observations and information stated during admission. If not formally assessed question-by-question, score using nurse's general description of resident's condition. Evaluate from mobility documentation - ambulates frequently and independently (walks frequently/4 points), limited walking with assistance (walks occasionally/3 points), wheelchair dependent or very limited mobility (chairfast/2 points), bedbound (bedfast/1 point).

Actual Question: Mobility - ability to change body position
Guidelines: Score based on nurse's observations and information stated during admission. If not formally assessed question-by-question, score using nurse's general description of resident's condition. Assess from positioning and movement observations - independent position changes (no limitations/4 points), frequent minor position adjustments (slightly limited/3 points), occasional slight movements only (very limited/2 points), requires assistance for all position changes (completely immobile/1 point).

Score based on nurse's observations and information stated during admission. If not formally assessed question-by-question, score using nurse's general description of resident's condition. Infer from eating patterns and dietary documentation - eats most meals completely (excellent/4 points), eats over half of meals (adequate/3 points), eats about half of offered food (probably inadequate/2 points), poor intake or NPO status (very poor/1 point).

Score based on nurse's observations and information stated during admission. If not formally assessed question-by-question, score using nurse's general description of resident's condition. Evaluate from transfer needs and positioning - independent movement without sliding (no problem/3 points), minimal assistance with occasional sliding (potential problem/2 points), requires maximum assistance with frequent repositioning (problem/1 point).

Score elopement risk using information from admission assessment. Calculate total risk score. If formal elopement screen not completed, score conservatively based on available observations. Assess from orientation documentation - fully oriented to person/place/time or comatose (0 points), oriented x2 or lethargic (2 points), oriented x1 or periodic confusion noted (4 points), alert but continuous confusion documented (5 points).

Score elopement risk using information from admission assessment. Calculate total risk score. If formal elopement screen not completed, score conservatively based on available observations. Infer from behavioral observations and history - no wandering behaviors documented and no elopement history (0 points), wandering noted but no elopement attempts (2 points), past elopement history but no recent exit-seeking (3 points), family concerns about leaving expressed (4 points), documented elopement history or current exit-seeking behaviors (5 points).

Score elopement risk using information from admission assessment. Calculate total risk score. If formal elopement screen not completed, score conservatively based on available observations. Evaluate from functional status documentation - bedbound or requires total assistance (0 points), independent wheelchair use (2 points), walks with assistive device (3 points), independent motorized wheelchair (4 points), ambulates independently without devices (5 points).

Score elopement risk using information from admission assessment. Calculate total risk score. If formal elopement screen not completed, score conservatively based on available observations. Assess from interactions and behavioral notes - content with facility placement (0 points), some discontent but agreeable (2 points), disagrees with placement (3 points), expresses desire to leave (4 points), actively attempting to exit (5 points).

Score elopement risk using information from admission assessment. Calculate total risk score. If formal elopement screen not completed, score conservatively based on available observations. Calculate total score: 0-9 (not at risk), 10-14 (at risk - requires picture in elopement book and wanderguard if available), 15+ (high risk - requires all interventions plus DON notification for interdisciplinary review). Score based on documented evidence rather than assumptions about potential behaviors.

Score elopement risk using information from admission assessment. Calculate total risk score. If formal elopement screen not completed, score conservatively based on available observations. Based on calculated elopement risk score: 0-9 points (not at risk - no interventions needed), 10-14 points (at risk - place picture in elopement book, apply wanderguard if available), 15+ points (high risk - place picture in elopement book, apply wanderguard if available, notify DON for interdisciplinary review).

Score elopement risk using information from admission assessment. Calculate total risk score. If formal elopement screen not completed, score conservatively based on available observations. If intervention review not explicitly documented but elopement risk identified, infer appropriate status: newly identified risk (interventions initiated), existing risk with ongoing monitoring (interventions reviewed), risk level changed or interventions not working (interventions modified).

Actual Question: Mental status - knows own ambulation limits
Guidelines: Evaluate from cognitive assessment and safety awareness - demonstrates understanding of mobility limitations and asks for help appropriately (0 points), overestimates abilities, attempts unsafe transfers, or forgets limitations (15 points).

Actual Question: Was resident admitted with active infection
Type of isolation precautions in place
Is resident totally dependent for positioning
Is resident unaware of safety deficiencies
Does resident have impaired trunk/sitting balance
Does resident have increased fall potential
Is resident using siderails for transfer/mobility
Is resident able to use call light
Resident totally dependent - rails not restraint
IDT review summary for siderail need
Does resident have vascular access device
Type of vascular access device present

Guidelines: If education not explicitly documented, infer from conditions and procedures: active diagnoses = disease management education, new medications = medication education, safety risks = safety education. Select multiple categories based on resident's needs.

Actual Question: RN Review - evaluation reviewed and approved
